channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Q. and A. on ISIS Hostages Held in Syria
item.description: Rukmini Callimachi, a Times reporter, answers readers’ questions about the 23 Western hostages who were held by the Islamic State in in Syria.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:credit: Glenna Gordon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nearly two dozen Western hostages held together in a 215-square-foot cell in Syria made a chess set from discarded pieces of paper.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong Politician Likens Protesters to African-American Slaves
item.description: A prominent businesswoman and politician has come under fire for saying, erroneously, that black Americans did not get voting rights for 107 years after the country’s slaves were freed, so Hong Kongers should also wait.
item.dc:creator: By SIOBHAN DOWNES

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong Protesters Consider Taking Their Grievances to Beijing
item.description: Alex Chow, one of the student leaders, said that the demonstrators were weighing whether to go to the Chinese capital when world leaders, including President Obama, gather for a summit meeting next week.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Hundreds of folded paper umbrellas, a symbol of the democracy movement, are strung across a street in Causeway Bay, Hong Kong.

item.title: U.N. Panel Faults Sri Lanka Over Presidential Powers
item.description: A human rights report criticized a constitutional change that allows the president to appoint or dismiss judges, and repealed the limit on presidential terms.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DHARISHA BASTIANS

item.title: Syrian Photographer’s Record of Deaths Generates Outrage, but Little Action
item.description: A celebrated defector is no longer optimistic that the United States has the will to stop the abuses committed by the Assad government.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: The Syrian defector and photographer known as Caesar, wearing a blue hooded jacket, listened to an interpreter at a briefing before the House Foreign Affairs Committee in July.

item.title: Blaise Compaoré Resigns as Burkina Faso’s President, and a General Assumes Power
item.description: Mr. Compaoré quit as violent protests to his 27-year reign in the West African nation showed no signs of winding down.
item.dc:creator: By HERVÉ TAOKO and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters gathered in Ouagadougou on Friday.

item.title: Sunni Tribesmen Say ISIS Exacts Brutal Revenge
item.description: Islamic State militants have killed scores of members of an Iraqi Sunni tribe that fought them for months, tribal leaders and officials said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Hungary Drops Internet Tax Plan After Surge of Protests
item.description: The proposal had been seen as a move by Prime Minister Viktor Orban to choke off one of the last sources of information not controlled by him and his allies.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Prolific Writer Clive James, Facing Death, Reflects on Getting ‘a Few Things Done’
item.description: Mr. James, 75, who has leukemia, continues to publish poetry and work on other projects in a career that has defied definition.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Hazel Thompson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Clive James has just published a book of writing on poetry and hopes to live long enough to see a new “Collected Poems,” scheduled for next year.

item.title: China and Russia Said to Block Creation of Antarctic Marine Reserves
item.description: International talks in Australia on establishing two marine reserve areas, each larger than Texas, in the waters around Antarctica ended in failure on Friday.
item.category: Commission for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Contested Holy Site in Jerusalem Reopens for Muslim Worship
item.description: Police officers were out in force and restricted access to the site, known to Jews as the Temple Mount and to Muslims as the Noble Sanctuary, barring men under 50.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and SAID GHAZALI

item.title: Braving Ebola
item.description: Portraits of those who labor and those who survived at an Ebola treatment center in rural Liberia.
item.dc:creator: By DANIEL BEREHULAK

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Hong Kong’s Occupy Generation
item.description: A new force is coming of age: young, dedicated to democracy, with little affinity for the cultural identity of mainland China.
item.dc:creator: By LIAN YI ZHENG

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing Police Clamp Down on Halloween Costumes in the Subway
item.description: Amid intense security as Beijing gears up to host the APEC summit meeting next week, the city’s traffic police asked people not to don Halloween costumes and get onto the city’s congested subway system, for fear of causing disturbances.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The Halloween tradition draws a mostly foreign crowd.

item.title: Taiwan’s President Backs Hong Kong Protesters While Courting Beijing
item.description: President Ma Ying-jeou of Taiwan said in an interview that he supported Hong Kong protesters’ democratic ideals, but would still pursue trade agreements with China.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Ma Ying-jeou of Taiwan at the presidential palace in Taipei on Friday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Larry Diamond on Political Change in Hong Kong
item.description: Larry Diamond, a political sociologist, discussed the prospects for political liberalization in Hong Kong and the Chinese mainland in light of the pro-democracy demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: By QITONG CAO

item.title: Sweden Gives Recognition to Palestinians
item.description: Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman of Israel said the decision by Stockholm was unfortunate and would strengthen radical elements and Palestinian recalcitrance.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Liberia’s Ebola Crisis Puts President in Harsh Light
item.description: As Liberia’s first elected leader after a devastating civil war, President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf has pushed the country to economic growth, but gains have been halted by the Ebola outbreak.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf of Liberia, center, with her security detail in August, visiting West Point, a neighborhood in Monrovia quarantined for Ebola.

item.title: Former Navy SEAL Team Member Investigated for Bin Laden Disclosures
item.description: A former Navy SEAL who wrote a best seller about the raid that killed Osama bin Laden is under criminal investigation for disclosing classified material.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
No Hero: The Evolution of a Navy SEAL (Book)
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER DREW and NICHOLAS KULISH

item.title: Family of Washington Post Reporter Calls on Iran to Free Him
item.description: Relatives of Jason Rezaian, held without explanation for more than two months, said “it’s time for Iran to concede Jason’s innocence and release him.”
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Jason Rezaian, an Iranian-American correspondent for The Washington Post, has spent 100 days in confinement.

item.title: New Russian Boldness Revives a Cold War Tradition: Testing the Other Side
item.description: A breach of a White House computer system and military flights skirting NATO territory could be “message-sending by Putin, and it’s dangerous,” a defense official said.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and NICOLE PERLROTH

item.title: Mexico City Journal: Halloween Creeps In Where Local Tradition Ruled the Living and Dead
item.description: As Mexicans prepare for the annual observance commemorating departed ancestors, they are also debating the influence of Halloween on the holiday.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: At the Sonora Market in downtown Mexico City, piñatas associated with Halloween were on display as the Day of the Dead holiday approached on Sunday.

item.title: Protest Is Muted as Egypt Levels Border Area in Sinai
item.description: The demolitions are part of a government plan to create a buffer to curb the flow of weapons and militants between Egypt and the Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: The Egyptian Army demolished homes in Rafah on Thursday to create a buffer against militants.

item.title: Open Source: Images of a Dramatic Day in Burkina Faso
item.description: Video and photographs shared online Thursday showed chaotic celebrations in the capital, Ouagadougou, as protesters toppled the government.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Protesters celebrated seizing the offices of state television in Burkina Faso's capital, Ouagadougou, on Thursday.

item.title: Warren Anderson, 92, Dies; Faced India Plant Disaster
item.description: Mr. Anderson led the company through one of history’s most lethal industrial accidents, when thousands were killed in a gas leak at its plant in India.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
